items.name: Hemoglobin
items.description: The protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen.
items.explanation: Your hemoglobin level is within the normal range, indicating proper oxygen transport in your body.
items.funFact: Did you know? Hemoglobin is like the delivery truck of your body, ensuring oxygen gets to where it's needed!
items.details: If hemoglobin levels drop, it can lead to anemia, making you feel tired or weak.

items.name: White Blood Cells (WBC)
items.description: Cells that help fight infections and protect against diseases.
items.explanation: A high WBC count might indicate an infection or inflammation in your body.
items.funFact: Did you know? White blood cells are like your body's soldiers, always on guard to fight off invaders!
items.details: Consult a doctor if WBC levels remain high for a prolonged period.

items.name: TSH (Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone)
items.description: Helps regulate the production of thyroid hormones.
items.explanation: Your TSH level is high, which could indicate an underactive thyroid (hypothyroidism).
items.funFact: Did you know? TSH is like the 'manager' of the thyroid factory, giving instructions to keep production on track!
items.details: You might feel tired or gain weight. Consult a healthcare professional for further evaluation.

items.name: Cortisol
items.description: A hormone released in response to stress.
items.explanation: Your cortisol level is within the normal range, indicating a healthy stress response.
items.funFact: Did you know? Cortisol is sometimes called the 'stress hormone' because it helps your body manage stress effectively!
items.details: If cortisol levels are too high for too long, it can lead to issues like anxiety or weight gain.
